Abstract

We investigate realizations of topological insulators with spin-1 bosons loaded in a honeycomb optical lattice and subjected to a Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) spin-orbit coupling - a situation which can be realized experimentally using cold atomic gases. In this paper, we focus on the topological properties of the single-particle band structure, namely Chern numbers (lattice with periodic boundary conditions) and edge states (lattice with strip geometry). While Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2) spin-orbit couplings always lead to time-reversal symmetric Hubbard models, and thereby to topologically trivial band structures, suitable Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) spin-orbit couplings can break time reversal symmetry and lead to topologically non-trivial bulk band structures and to edge states in the strip geometry. In addition, we show that one can trigger a series of topological transitions (i.e. integer changes of the Chern numbers) that are specific to the geometry of the honeycomb lattice by varying a single parameter in the Hamiltonian.

I Introduction

Over the last few years, the continuous progress in the degree of control, tunability and flexibility of ultracold atomic gases experiments Lewenstein07 ; Blochreview08 ; Ketterle2 has opened the lab door to a whole class of model Hamiltonians, as witnessed for example by the recent implementation of artificial gauge fieldsÂ Spielman09a ; Spielman09b ; Spielman11 ; Zhang12 ; Zwierlein12 ; Windpassinger12 ; Spielman12 . Some of these model Hamiltonians are directly inherited from condensed matter physics, for instance the integer and fractional quantum Hall effectsÂ FCI13 ; FCIPRL1 ; FCIPRL2 . More saliently, physicists have further proposed new theoretical ideas and physical situations, such as topological phasesÂ Mottonen09 ; Bercioux11 ; Hueda12 ; YuXin15 ; Goldman2016 ; Zhai2015 , non-Abelian particlesÂ Burrello10 or mixed dimensional systemsÂ Nishida_2008 ; Nishida_2010 ; Lamporesi_2010 ; Huang_2013 ; Iskin_2010 , that could be tested in the lab. In particular, experiments involving spinors, either made of bosons or fermions in different Zeeman sub-levels, are now able to implement and study non-Abelian gauge fieldsÂ Goldman2016 ; Livi2016 ; Gross2017 ; Sugawa2016 ; Ray2014 . In these systems, the kinetic energy term in the Hamiltonian allows for a modification of the internal degrees of freedom as the particle propagatesÂ Dalibard11 ; Goldman2013 , leading to a rich class of non trivial physical phenomena, especially with interactions. In two-dimensional lattices, and in particular when spin-orbit coupling is present, the corresponding non-Abelian gauge fields induce non-diagonal hopping matrices in the tight-binding Hubbard Hamiltonian that mix and flip the spin degrees of freedomÂ Dalibard11 ; Goldman2013 . 2-component bosonic and fermionic gases (in the bulk or in a lattice) have been the subject of many recent analytical and numerical studiesÂ Lewenstein09 ; Cole_2012 ; Cai12 ; Galitski12 ; Hofstetter12 ; Fujimoto09 ; Goldman12 ; Jiri2014 ; Shenoy11 ; Sademelo12 ; Lewenstein10 ; Iskin11 ; Iskin12 ; Iskin13 ; Riedl13 .

In marked contrast, 3-component bosonic or fermionic gases subjected to a Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) gauge field have been much less studied: the experimental realization is more complicatedÂ Dalibard11 ; YuXin2014 ; Kosior2014 and their theoretical studies are more involved, the gauge field group being much largerÂ Barnett2012 ; Mandal2016 ; Han2016 ; Grass2014 ; Go2013 . On the other hand, tight-binding models with a Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) spin-orbit coupling can break time reversal symmetry and lead to topological insulators: the bulk band structure is topologically non trivial (non-zero Chern numbers) and edge states develop for a strip geometryÂ Barnett2012 . Such a situation cannot occur in any kind of Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2) models as we will explain later. In addition, since Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) has a more complex group structure than Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2), one expects a larger variety of spin textures for interacting particles. These spin textures are associated to different homotopy groups and appear both in the ground state and in the excitations above the ground stateÂ Hueda12 ; Ezawa_book ; Mandal2016 ; Han2016 ; Grass2014 ; Go2013 .

Our paper consists of three main parts. In SectionÂ II, we give some general properties of Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(N)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆğ‘SU(N) Hubbard models and describe the Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) tight-binding model on the honeycomb lattice that we consider. We analyze its time-reversal properties. In SectionÂ III we study the topological properties of the band structure obtained for a lattice with periodic boundary conditions and compute the corresponding Chern numbersÂ Resta2000 ; Paly2016 ; Niu2010 ; Houches2014 . Next we study the edge states that are expected in the lattice strip geometry, as inferred from the bulk-edge correspondenceÂ Hatsugai1993a ; Hatsugai1993b ; Hatsugai1997 ; Kane2005 ; Kane2010 . In SectionÂ IV, we show how to trigger a series of topological transitions in the band structure of our Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) model (i.e. integer changes in the Chern numbers) by varying a single parameter in the Hamiltonian. The variety of such topological transitions is richer on the honeycomb lattice than on the square lattice. In SectionÂ V, we summarize our results and conclude with some perspectives.

Chern numbers of a given tight-binding Hamiltonian satisfy a â€zero-sum ruleâ€: they all add up to zero. For inversion-symmetric systems (resp. for time-reversal invariant systems), it is well known that the Berry curvature is even (resp. odd) in the Bâ€‹Zğµğ‘BZ:

Î©n(ğ¤)={+Î©nâ€‹(âˆ’ğ¤)â€‹inversionâ€‹symmetryâˆ’Î©nâ€‹(âˆ’ğ¤)â€‹timeâ€‹reversalâ€‹symmetry.\displaystyle\Omega_{n}(\mathbf{k})=\left\{\begin{matrix}+\Omega_{n}(-\mathbf{k})\ \mathrm{inversion\ symmetry}\phantom{blah}\\ -\Omega_{n}(-\mathbf{k})\ \mathrm{time\ reversal\ symmetry}\end{matrix}\right..

These two properties show that: (i) the Berry curvature itself identically vanishes if H^^ğ»\hat{H} is invariant under both space inversion and time reversal; (ii) Chern numbers of time-reversal invariant Hamiltonians are necessarily vanishing. Therefore, only systems that break time reversal symmetry can have non-trivial topological properties, i.e. non-vanishing Chern numbers. II.2 Non-Abelian Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) model on the honeycomb lattice

III Topological properties

III.2 Finite system - Edge states

As is well known, a lattice Hamiltonian having a band structure with non-vanishing Chern numbers exhibits edge states in a strip geometryÂ Kane2010 . We consider such a finite lattice strip for our Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) model and compute the spectrum for open boundary conditions in the ğš1subscriptğš1\mathbf{a}_{1} direction (0â‰¤n1â‰¤N0subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘0\leq n_{1}\leq N) and periodic boundary conditions in the ğš2subscriptğš2\mathbf{a}_{2} direction (unrestricted n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}). The lattice strip we consider has left and right zig-zag boundaries. Since the Hamiltonian is still invariant under lattice translations along ğš2subscriptğš2\mathbf{a}_{2}, the Bloch wavevector along ğ›2subscriptğ›2\mathbf{b}_{2} remains a good quantum number. Therefore, we introduce the Fourier transform operators ğš^n1,k2subscript^ğšsubscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘˜2\hat{\mathbf{a}}_{n_{1},k_{2}} and ğ›^n1,k2subscript^ğ›subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘˜2\hat{\mathbf{b}}_{n_{1},k_{2}} along ğš2subscriptğš2\mathbf{a}_{2}. The Hamiltonian, for a given Bloch wavevector k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, now reads:

H^k2=âˆ’tâ€‹âˆ‘n1=0Nsubscript^ğ»subscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘›10ğ‘\displaystyle\hat{H}_{k_{2}}=-t\sum_{n_{1}=0}^{N} ğ›^n1,k2â€ â€‹(eiâ€‹ğ¤2â‹…ğœ¹1â€‹ğŸ™+ğ•–ğ•šâ€‹ğ¤ğŸšâ‹…ğœ¹ğŸ›â€‹ğ’°)â€‹ğš^ğ•ŸğŸ™,ğ•œğŸšsubscriptsuperscript^ğ›â€ subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘’â‹…ğ‘–subscriptğ¤2subscriptğœ¹1ğŸ™superscriptğ•–â‹…ğ•šsubscriptğ¤2subscriptğœ¹3ğ’°subscriptsuperscript^ğšabsentsubscriptğ•Ÿ1subscriptğ•œ2\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1},k_{2}}(e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{1}}\openone+e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{3}}\mathcal{U})\,\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\phantom{\dagger}}_{n_{1},k_{2}}
âˆ’tâ€‹âˆ‘n1=1Nğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘›11ğ‘\displaystyle-t\sum_{n_{1}=1}^{N} ğ›^n1âˆ’1,k2â€ â€‹eiâ€‹ğ¤2â‹…ğœ¹2â€‹ğ’Ÿâ€‹ğš^n1,k2+H.c.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript^ğ›â€ subscriptğ‘›11subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘’â‹…ğ‘–subscriptğ¤2subscriptğœ¹2ğ’Ÿsubscriptsuperscript^ğšabsentsubscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘˜2Hc\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1}-1,k_{2}}e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{2}}\mathcal{D}\,\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\phantom{\dagger}}_{n_{1},k_{2}}+\mathrm{H.c.} (14)

with |k2|â‰¤1/2subscriptğ‘˜212|k_{2}|\leq 1/2. By diagonalizing H^k2subscript^ğ»subscriptğ‘˜2\hat{H}_{k_{2}}, we obtain the band spectrum shown in Fig.Â 3. This spectrum has to be compared to the bulk spectrum, shown in Fig.Â 4, that has been obtained for the same number of cells Nğ‘N along ğš1subscriptğš1\mathbf{a}_{1} but with periodic boundary conditions. As expected from our analysis of the bulk spectrum, we indeed find additional states in the gaps between bands with different Chern numbers, that is between the first and second bands, between the second and third bands and, by symmetry, between the fourth and fifth bands and between the fifth and sixth bands. No additional states appear between the third and the fourth band, since these two bands have equal Chern numbers.

Let us define the position xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} (i=1,â€¦,2â€‹Nğ‘–1â€¦2ğ‘i=1,\ldots,2N) of the sites along a given horizontal zig-zag chain crossing the lattice strip from left to right. We denote by Pnâ€‹(xi,k2)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜2P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2}) the spatial distribution of the eigenstate with eigenvalue Ïµnâ€‹(k2)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›subscriptğ‘˜2\epsilon_{n}(k_{2}) along this chain. The color scale of Fig.Â 3 shows the average position dn=âˆ‘ixiâ€‹Pnâ€‹(xi,k2)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜2d_{n}=\sum_{i}x_{i}P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2}) of the eigenstate in the strip. We see that states chosen within the bulk-like bands spread uniformly over the whole lattice strip and dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{n} lies at the center of the lattice strip. On the contrary, states connecting bulk-like bands with different Chern numbers are either strongly localized on the left boundary (black) or on the right boundary (green) of the lattice: these are the celebrated edge states. We also see that, in our system, edge states within a given gap are localized on one side of the strip when their group velocity is positive and on the other side of the strip when their group velocity is negative. This one-to-one correspondence between the sign of the slope of the energy dispersion relation of an edge state and its spatial localization changes from one gap to the other. This feature, particular to our system, emphasizes the chiral character expected for particle transport at the boundaries. Interestingly, one can recover the values of the Chern numbers of our bulk system from the bulk-edge correspondence Â Hatsugai1993a ; Hatsugai1993b ; Hatsugai1997 . Within a given gap, one counts the number of edge state N+subscriptğ‘N_{+} and Nâˆ’subscriptğ‘N_{-} with positive and negative group velocities that give rise to a localization on the right side of the strip. The difference (N+âˆ’Nâˆ’)subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘(N_{+}-N_{-}) is then equal to the sum of the Chern numbers of all the bands below the gap considered. This recipe allows to reconstruct all Chern numbers with their sign. It is easy to check that we do recover the values computed in the preceding paragraph. For instance, the absence of edge states linking the third and the fourth bands (N+=Nâˆ’=0subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘0N_{+}=N_{-}=0) is in agreement with the fact that the sum of the Chern numbers of the three lowest bands vanishes, N+âˆ’Nâˆ’=C1+C2+C3=0subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ¶30N_{+}-N_{-}=C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}=0.

The probability distribution Pnâ€‹(xi,k2)âˆeÎ³â€‹xiproportional-tosubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘’ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2})\propto e^{\gamma x_{i}} of an edge state decays exponentially with xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} when it is localized at n1=0subscriptğ‘›10n_{1}=0 (Î³<0ğ›¾0\gamma<0) and grows exponentially with xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} when it is localized at n1=Nsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘n_{1}=N (Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0). The (positive or negative) value of the characteristic scale 1/Î³1ğ›¾1/\gamma depends both on the edge state considered and on the Bloch wavector k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}. This is emphasized in Fig.Â 5b where we plot Î³ğ›¾\gamma as a function of k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} for the edge states with the dispersion relation highlighted in Fig.Â 5a. As one can see, the state is localized on the left side of the strip (n1=0subscriptğ‘›10n_{1}=0) as long as its group velocity is negative. For values of k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} roughly in the range 0.6âˆ’0.70.60.70.6-0.7, the state dives into the bulk band and becomes delocalized. The decay coefficient Î³ğ›¾\gamma then vanishes. For larger k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} values, the group velocity becomes positive and the state is now localized on the right side of the strip (n1=Nsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘n_{1}=N). Finally, Fig.Â 5c shows the probability distribution Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{n} for the different edge states shown in Fig.Â 5a) for a given value of k2â‰ƒ0.458similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘˜20.458k_{2}\simeq 0.458. Here again, one can see the correlation observed in our system between the sign of the group velocity and the localization center of the edge state.

IV Topological transitions

The Chern number of a given isolated band is an invariant integer-valued topological quantity. Its value can only change when the band comes in contact with another one. A vanishing gap can be achieved by changing parameters in the Hamiltonian, for example the strength of the spin-orbit coupling. In general, the hopping matrices along links ğœ¹asubscriptğœ¹ğ‘\bm{\delta}_{a} can be written as Ta=âˆ’tâ€‹expâ¡(iâ€‹Aa)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘¡isubscriptğ´ğ‘T_{a}=-t\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{a})} (a=1,2,3ğ‘123a=1,2,3). The traceless Hermitian featuring gauge field can be written as Aa=ğœ¶aâ‹…ğ€subscriptğ´ğ‘â‹…subscriptğœ¶ğ‘ğ€A_{a}=\bm{\alpha}_{a}\cdot\bm{\lambda}, where ğœ¶asubscriptğœ¶ğ‘\bm{\alpha}_{a} is a real 8-component vector and ğ€ğ€\bm{\lambda} is the 8-component vector made of the Gell-Mann matrices. We have first monitored the band structure, gaps and Chern numbers by considering various configurations of the three vectors ğœ¶asubscriptğœ¶ğ‘\bm{\alpha}_{a}. However, for all configurations that we tested, we could only recover the set of Chern numbers (3,âˆ’6,3)363(3,-6,3) already found in SectionÂ III for the 3 negative bands, or the opposite set (âˆ’3,6,âˆ’3)363(-3,6,-3). The same result was obtained by allowing for imbalanced tunneling amplitudes, that is Ta=âˆ’taâ€‹expâ¡(iâ€‹Aa)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘isubscriptğ´ğ‘T_{a}=-t_{a}\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{a})}, and by varying the tasubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{a}.

More saliently, we found other topological transitions giving rise to different sets of Chern numbers by adding a spin-dependent chemical potential term âˆ’(Î¼Aâ€‹nA+Î¼Bâ€‹nB)subscriptğœ‡ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğœ‡ğµsubscriptğ‘›ğµ-(\mu_{A}n_{A}+\mu_{B}n_{B}) to the Hamiltonian. The chemical potential matrix for Ağ´A sites reads Î¼A=âˆ’Î”/2â€‹ğŸ™+Î´â€‹Î¼ğ”¸â€‹ğ•Šğ•«subscriptğœ‡ğ´Î”2ğŸ™ğ›¿subscriptğœ‡ğ”¸subscriptğ•Šğ•«\mu_{A}=-\Delta/2\,\openone+\delta\mu_{A}S_{z} and Î¼B=Î”/2â€‹ğŸ™+Î´â€‹Î¼ğ”¹â€‹ğ•Šğ•«subscriptğœ‡ğµÎ”2ğŸ™ğ›¿subscriptğœ‡ğ”¹subscriptğ•Šğ•«\mu_{B}=\Delta/2\,\openone+\delta\mu_{B}S_{z} for BğµB sites. Note that Î”Î”\Delta is the usual (spin-independent) mass term (see SectionÂ III). All in all, we found that the two following spin-dependent chemical potential configurations

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Î´â€‹Î¼B=Î´â€‹Î¼Ağ›¿subscriptğœ‡ğµğ›¿subscriptğœ‡ğ´\delta\mu_{B}=\delta\mu_{A} (spin-dependent local potential).

with an additional spin-orbit coupling along ğœ¹1subscriptğœ¹1\bm{\delta}_{1} gave rise to a larger variety of Chern numbers. We point out that, without this additional spin-orbit coupling, one can still find Chern numbers differing from Â±(3,âˆ’6,3)plus-or-minus363\pm(3,-6,3), but only for some particular values of the spin-orbit couplings along ğœ¹2subscriptğœ¹2\bm{\delta}_{2} and ğœ¹3subscriptğœ¹3\bm{\delta}_{3}.

As an example, we consider a system with spin-dependent mass imbalance (Î”Sâ‰ 0subscriptÎ”ğ‘†0\Delta_{S}\neq 0) and non-Abelian hopping matrices T1=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’±=âˆ’tâ€‹expâ¡(iâ€‹A1)subscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘¡ğ’±ğ‘¡isubscriptğ´1T_{1}=-t\,\mathcal{V}=-t\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{1})} where A1=2â€‹Ï€3â€‹3â€‹(Î»1+Î»4+Î»6)subscriptğ´12ğœ‹33subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†4subscriptğœ†6A_{1}=\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{4}+\lambda_{6}), T2=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘‡2ğ‘¡ğ’ŸT_{2}=-t\,\mathcal{D} and T3=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’°subscriptğ‘‡3ğ‘¡ğ’°T_{3}=-t\,\mathcal{U}. For sake of simplicity, we also choose Î”=0Î”0\Delta=0. Fig.Â 6 shows the 6 Chern numbers Cnsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›C_{n} and the different band gaps that are obtained as a function of Î”SsubscriptÎ”ğ‘†\Delta_{S}. As one can see, we get new sets of Chern numbers now and not just Â±(3,âˆ’6,3)plus-or-minus363\pm(3,-6,3), see TableÂ 1. The vertical lines in Fig.Â 6 are guides to the eye that mark a gap closing between 2 adjacent bands. We see that the different gaps do not close at the same time. This emphasizes that it is only the pair of Chern numbers Cn+1subscriptğ¶ğ‘›1C_{n+1} and Cnsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›C_{n} of the bands involved in the gap closing gn+1,n=0subscriptğ‘”ğ‘›1ğ‘›0g_{n+1,n}=0 that can change. One has:

(Cn+1+Cn)after=(Cn+1+Cn)before,subscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›1subscriptğ¶ğ‘›aftersubscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›1subscriptğ¶ğ‘›before\displaystyle\left(C_{n+1}+C_{n}\right)_{\textrm{after}}=\left(C_{n+1}+C_{n}\right)_{\textrm{before}}, (15)

the other Chern numbers remain unaffected. We further note that changing the sign of all the mass imbalances amounts to flipping the sign of the eigenvalues of the Hamiltonian, Ïµnâ€‹(ğ¤,âˆ’Î”,âˆ’Î”S)=âˆ’Ïµ7âˆ’nâ€‹(ğ¤,Î”,Î”S)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›ğ¤Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†subscriptitalic-Ïµ7ğ‘›ğ¤Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k},-\Delta,-\Delta_{S})=-\,\epsilon_{7-n}(\mathbf{k},\Delta,\Delta_{S}). Again, this is because Pâ€‹â„‹ğ¤â€‹(Î”,Î”S)â€‹P=âˆ’â„‹ğ¤â€‹(âˆ’Î”,âˆ’Î”S)ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„‹ğ¤Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„‹ğ¤Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†P\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}(\Delta,\Delta_{S})P=-\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}(-\Delta,-\Delta_{S}). We therefore have the property that C7âˆ’nâ€‹(Î”,Î”S)=Cnâ€‹(âˆ’Î”,âˆ’Î”S)subscriptğ¶7ğ‘›Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†subscriptğ¶ğ‘›Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†C_{7-n}(\Delta,\Delta_{S})=C_{n}(-\Delta,-\Delta_{S}). This symmetry in the Chern numbers can be readily checked in Fig.Â 6 obtained for Î”=0Î”0\Delta=0. One also confirms that gaps have the same symmetry, gn+1,nâ€‹(Î”S)=g7âˆ’n,6âˆ’nâ€‹(âˆ’Î”S)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘›1ğ‘›subscriptÎ”ğ‘†subscriptğ‘”7ğ‘›6ğ‘›subscriptÎ”ğ‘†g_{n+1,n}(\Delta_{S})=g_{7-n,6-n}(-\Delta_{S}), from which one concludes that g43subscriptğ‘”43g_{43} is symmetric in Î”SsubscriptÎ”ğ‘†\Delta_{S}. We also note that the gap g43subscriptğ‘”43g_{43} only closes at Î”S=0subscriptÎ”ğ‘†0\Delta_{S}=0 but that this degeneracy does not modify C3subscriptğ¶3C_{3} and C4subscriptğ¶4C_{4}. As a consequence, the change in Chern numbers after a gap closing can only occur within the subset (C1,C2,C3)subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ¶3(C_{1},C_{2},C_{3}) or within (C4,C5,C6)subscriptğ¶4subscriptğ¶5subscriptğ¶6(C_{4},C_{5},C_{6}). The Chern numbers thus satisfy again the separate zero-sum rules C1+C2+C3=C4+C5+C6=0subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ¶3subscriptğ¶4subscriptğ¶5subscriptğ¶60C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}=C_{4}+C_{5}+C_{6}=0. Finally all bands eventually reach a vanishing Chern number for large enough values of |Î”S|subscriptÎ”ğ‘†|\Delta_{S}|, even though the Berry curvatures neither vanish nor display any particular symmetry. Fig.Â 7 shows a plot of the Berry curvature of the second band Ïµ2â€‹(ğ¤,Î”S)subscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ¤subscriptÎ”ğ‘†\epsilon_{2}(\mathbf{k},\Delta_{S}) in the Brillouin zone obtained for Î”S=âˆ’2.6subscriptÎ”ğ‘†2.6\Delta_{S}=-2.6 where C2=1subscriptğ¶21C_{2}=1 (top plot) and for Î”S=âˆ’4subscriptÎ”ğ‘†4\Delta_{S}=-4 where C2=0subscriptğ¶20C_{2}=0 (bottom plot). In both cases, the Berry curvatures exhibit qualitatively similar structures.

As explained above, such a rich variety of Chern numbers and topological transitions have been obtained by imposing spin-dependent chemical potentials on sites Ağ´A and BğµB and different spin-orbit couplings along the 3 links, keeping intact, at the same time, the underlying triangular Bravais symmetry of the honeycomb lattice. We have studied the same situation on the square lattice (not shown here) but were not able to find such a rich variety of Chern numbers and topological transitions. The probable reason is that the square lattice has only 2 link vectors and thus accommodates less configurations of spin-orbit couplings. From that point of view, the Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) model on the honeycomb lattice exhibits a band structure with richer topological properties.

A similarly rich variety of topological transitions and Chern numbers is obtained by allowing for complex ğœ¶asubscriptğœ¶ğ‘\bm{\alpha}_{a} in the gauge fields Aa=ğœ¶aâ‹…ğ€subscriptğ´ğ‘â‹…subscriptğœ¶ğ‘ğ€A_{a}=\bm{\alpha}_{a}\cdot\bm{\lambda}. However, this situation, even if experimentally feasible, does not correspond to a pure Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) gauge potential anymore.

We emphasize that the bulk bands remain well isolated for a large variety of gauge fields Aasubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{a} and for many values of the the spin-dependent mass imbalance Î”SsubscriptÎ”ğ‘†\Delta_{S}. However, even though the bands do not touch at any point in the Brillouin zone, they can still overlap on the energy axis, which means that there is no charge gap separating them. This situation is depicted in Fig.Â 8 for Î”=Î”S=0Î”subscriptÎ”ğ‘†0\Delta=\Delta_{S}=0, T1=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’°subscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘¡ğ’°T_{1}=-t\,\mathcal{U}, T2=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘‡2ğ‘¡ğ’ŸT_{2}=-t\,\mathcal{D} and T3=âˆ’tâ€‹ğ’±subscriptğ‘‡3ğ‘¡ğ’±T_{3}=-t\,\mathcal{V}. But, since the Chern numbers are still well defined, topological edge states linking the different bands still appear in the strip lattice configuration. On the other hand, the absence of charge gaps prevents the system from behaving like a Chern insulator and no Hall plateaus are then expected in transverse conductance measurements.

V Conclusion

We have studied the topological properties of a non-interacting Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice with Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) spin-orbit couplings. We have emphasized that, in marked contrast with lattice Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2) models which are always topologically trivial, these Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) models can break time reversal invariance. As a consequence, their bulk band structure becomes topologically non trivial: bulk bands have non-zero Chern numbers and chiral edge states develop in a lattice strip configuration with open boundary conditions. We have also shown that Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) models on the honeycomb lattice allow for a larger variety of topological transitions than on the square latticeÂ Barnett2012 because of a higher lattice coordination number.

A natural extension of the present work is to include interactions in our model and understand their impact on the topological properties of the system, in particular the emergence of non-trivial spin textures breaking the translation symmetry of the latticeÂ Cole_2012 ; Hofstetter12 ; Grass2014 ; Mandal2016 . Because Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3SU(3) is a larger gauge group than Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2), we expect a much larger variety of topological properties for these spin texturesÂ Hueda12 ; Ezawa_book .

This can be directly checked from the matrix expression given above. This result is in fact general: any unitary NÃ—Nğ‘ğ‘N\times N matrix which is even under time reversal is unimodular.

If Uğ‘ˆU is odd under time reversal, a convenient parametrization is:

This results holds true for any unitary NÃ—Nğ‘ğ‘N\times N matrix which is odd under time reversal provided Nğ‘N is odd.
